description.narrative:
This project forms part of a series of 3 pilot initiatives called test cases for the project Deepening Democracy, coming out of several years of North South exchanges of innovative citizens driven solutions to social problems. With Deepening Democracy, E-Motive is changing from wide spread thematic focus to a one issue focus, in order to use expertise of different countries to tackle one global issue in-depth. Key for the way of working is mutual learning where the North and the South are learning from each other horizontally. The project deepening Democracy aims to change the role of citizens in (the) policy development (cycle) by increasing their influece and by creating the ability to hold representatives accountable for their actions and make their policies more responsive to their direct concerns and priorities.
The test cases of 2015 will provide input for the development of the longterm project Deepening Democracy. The test cases will test innovative solutions (tools) for deepening democracy in new contexts and linking up with tools form different context.
The project managed by CEW-IT will further elaborate and expand the Youth Manifesto tool of CEW-IT for agenda-setting, zooming in on the theme of youth unemployment, and link that tool to the ongoing initiatives towards young citizens’ agenda-setting of INESC and Movisie, and made compatibel to their influencing and edutainment tools. The thematically focussed and customized tool will be implemented in the three countries.
The pilot, thematically focussing and customizing the Youth Manifesto tool for youth unemployment, provides an in-road for youth citizens to express what they think should be undertaken to effectively combat youth unemployment for all segments of young people, and hold their governments accountable for more effective and responsive youth unemployment policies. This helps youth and groups of young citizens to expresses their views and priorities and influence the setting of the political agenda on youth employment, demand responsiveness and advocate for policy changes.

participating-org.narrative: The Citizens Watch # IT was founded in 2010 by four regional organizations # RWECO, CEFORD, PAC-U and ACORD as a loose consortium to mobilize Ugandans to monitor and influence electoral and democratic processes in Uganda. It was originally called Citizens Elections Watch with Information Technology to specifically reflect the original mandate of elections monitoring. However, CEW-IT#s mandatehas since broadened from only focusing on elections monitoring to cover governance and livelihoods improvement. In reflection of this broadened mandate has changed names to Citizens Watch with Information Technology (CEW-IT). CEW-IT was incorporated in May 2012 as CEW-IT Uganda Ltd to meet four main objectives all of which point to enhancing civic competence to improve livelihoods and hence reduce poverty. Therefore CEW-IT is now no longer a loose coalition but a body corporate with its own secretariat headed by the National Coordinator. CEW-IT has also broadened its membership by bringing on board two national level organizations as affiliate members, namely, the Development Network of Voluntary Associations (DENIVA) which is focusing on Bukedi, Busoga, Buganda, Ankole and Kigezi sub regions and the Foundation for Human Rights Initiative (FHRI) that is working in the Buganda region districts of Luwero, Kiboga, Kayunga, Kalangala and Mpigi. For this particular action CEW-IT will work with its four original members plus DENIVA.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
